content.title: Practice knowledge test
content.failingResultsBody: A passing score of 80% is required on the real test.
content.message: Need to study before your knowledge test? Check out the Learn to Drive Smart Manual.

question.text: To identify hazards in your surroundings while driving, you should

answers.answer: scan the driving environment regularly
answers.distractor_1: only keep your eyes directly on the road ahead
answers.distractor_2: avoid using your rear view mirrors
answers.distractor_3: tune your radio to receive local traffic information

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do
question.source: Do not overdrive your ability to see. You should always be able to prepare for a potential hazard instead of being taken by surprise.

question.text: On a vehicle with AUTOMATIC transmission, when should the first and second DRIVE (D1, D2) gears be used

answers.answer: when pulling heavy loads or when going up or down very steep hills.
answers.distractor_1: when exiting a highway.
answers.distractor_2: when parking your vehicle.
answers.distractor_3: when it is raining.

question.chapter: Chapter 2: You and Your Vehicle; Comparing Automatic and Standard Transmissions
question.source: There are two types of transmissions: automatic and standard. Both control the connection between the engine and the wheels.

question.text: Which of the following is NOT part of the pre-trip check you should do EVERY time you drive?

answers.answer: Check radiator fluid and oil levels.
answers.distractor_1: Check side and rear view mirrors are properly adjusted.
answers.distractor_2: Check head rest and seat belts are properly adjusted.
answers.distractor_3: Check lights and turn signals.

question.chapter: Chapter 2: You and Your Vehicle; Pre-trip Check.
question.source: To ensure good maintenance, you need to do a more thorough pre-trip check every few weeks.

question.text: Seat belts are most effective in preventing injury when

answers.answer: the lap belt and shoulder strap are worn correctly.
answers.distractor_1: the head rest is fully extended.
answers.distractor_2: the seat is moved fully forward.
answers.distractor_3: the seat is tilted back slightly.

question.chapter: Chapter 2: You and Your Vehicle; Seatbelts
question.source: Wearing a seatbelt significantly reduces your chance of serious injury or death in a crash.

question.text: As a driver you should

answers.answer: constantly check the sides of the road and all of your mirrors, as well as the road ahead
answers.distractor_1: carefully watch the car behind you
answers.distractor_2: carefully watch the car ahead of you
answers.distractor_3: rarely look in your mirrors

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Observation
question.source: It is important that you pay attention to things outside your central vision. Peripheral vision allows you to see more than what is directly in front of you.

question.text: When making a right turn, you should shoulder check to

answers.answer: make sure a cyclist or other road user is not beside you
answers.distractor_1: make sure you are in the proper lane
answers.distractor_2: warn the car behind of your intent to turn
answers.distractor_3: make sure the car behind you is not too close

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Observation
question.source: Whenever you plan a change in direction or road position, do a shoulder check to make sure the blind spot on that side is clear.

question.text: The correct See-Think-Do strategy for the driver of Car A is?

answers.answer: Sees that Car B is close behind; thinks, "I need more space."; slows and gradually leaves a bigger cushion in front.
answers.distractor_1: Sees that Car B is close behind; thinks, "I need to get away."; accelerates to leave more space behind.
answers.distractor_2: Sees there is small gap to the right of Truck C; thinks, "I can squeeze through there."; accelerates and changes lanes.
answers.distractor_3: Sees that Car B is close behind; thinks, "I need more space."; brakes suddenly to scare driver of Car B.

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do
question.source: it's a good idea to slow down slightly to increase your space in front. This way, if you have to stop, you can stop more gradually ...

question.text: When do you NOT need to make a shoulder check?

answers.answer: When judging your following distance.
answers.distractor_1: When you pull out from the side of the road.
answers.distractor_2: When you pull over to the side of the road.
answers.distractor_3: When you change lanes.

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Observation
question.source: Whenever you plan a change in direction or road position, do a shoulder check to make sure the blind spot on that side is clear.

question.text: There is a vehicle directly in the blind spot of Car A, which one is it?

answers.answer: Car D
answers.distractor_1: Car C
answers.distractor_2: Car B
answers.distractor_3: Car E

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Observation
question.source: Even when your mirrors are properly adjusted, there are large areas that you can't see in your mirrors. These are called blind spots.

question.text: The best way to check for vehicles in the blind spots is by

answers.answer: looking over your shoulder
answers.distractor_1: keeping clear of other vehicles
answers.distractor_2: checking side and rearview mirrors
answers.distractor_3: scanning for blind spots ahead of you

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Observation
question.source: Whenever you plan a change in direction or road position, do a shoulder check to make sure the blind spot on that side is clear.

question.text: Reaction time is affected most after

answers.answer: drinking alcohol
answers.distractor_1: exercising
answers.distractor_2: sleeping
answers.distractor_3: working hard

question.chapter: Chapter 7: Personal Strategies; Facts About Alcohol
question.source: In some cases, even small amounts of alcohol can cause a driver to be impaired.

question.text: What is this cyclist going to do?

answers.answer: Stop or slow down.
answers.distractor_1: Turn right.
answers.distractor_2: Turn left.
answers.distractor_3: Let you pass.

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Communication
question.source: This section has an illustration that shows how cyclists signal left turns, right turns, and stopping or slowing down.

question.text: A driver should not change lanes

answers.answer: in intersections
answers.distractor_1: at less than 50km/h
answers.distractor_2: at more than 80km/h
answers.distractor_3: in hospital zones

question.chapter: Chapter 4: Rules of the Road
question.source: Don't change lanes at an intersection. You could confuse other drivers and cause a crash.

question.text: Unless otherwise posted, the speed limit WITHIN cities and towns is

answers.answer: 50km/h
answers.distractor_1: 30km/h
answers.distractor_2: 60km/h
answers.distractor_3: 80km/h

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Speed Control
question.source: Unless a sign tells you otherwise, the speed limit is 50km/h within cities and towns.

question.text: What should the driver of Car A do?

answers.answer: Slow down to allow Car B safe entry.
answers.distractor_1: Speed up to get ahead of merging Car B.
answers.distractor_2: Slow down, honk, and wave Car B in.
answers.distractor_3: Maintain speed.

question.chapter: Chapter 4: Rules of the Road; Highway or Freeway Entrances and Exits
question.source: When you are driving in the right lane of a freeway, other drivers may try to merge from an entrance lane. It's not always easy for them to find a safe gap.

question.text: Before you pull out to pass, you should

answers.answer: be able to see well ahead
answers.distractor_1: get close to the vehicle ahead
answers.distractor_2: wait for a signal from the driver ahead
answers.distractor_3: speed up and watch carefully

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Assess the Risk
question.source: In assessing just how risky this situation is, you should ask yourself what could happen. What if there is an unexpected obstacle just around the curve?

question.text: You should NOT pass another vehicle

answers.answer: when your vision is obstructed
answers.distractor_1: on an unfamiliar road
answers.distractor_2: on a 2-lane road at night
answers.distractor_3: on a multi-lane one way street

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Hazard Perception
question.source: Be extra cautious when anything blocks your view. Never pass when you are approaching the top of a hill.

question.text: It is illegal to exceed the posted speed limit

answers.answer: at all times
answers.distractor_1: except in remote or unpopulated areas
answers.distractor_2: except when you are keeping up with traffic
answers.distractor_3: except when passing

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Speed Control
question.source: The posted speed is the maximum for ideal conditions only. Choose a lower speed if the conditions are not ideal.

question.text: If you are behind a large vehicle or a motorcycle on a high speed road, your following distance should be at LEAST

answers.answer: 3 seconds
answers.distractor_1: 4 seconds
answers.distractor_2: 2 seconds
answers.distractor_3: 6 seconds

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Space Margins
question.source: Allow at least three seconds following distance when you are behind a large vehicle that could block your vision or a motorcycle that could stop very quickly.

question.text: In bad weather or slippery conditions on high speed roads, your following distance should be at LEAST

answers.answer: 4 seconds
answers.distractor_1: 2 seconds
answers.distractor_2: 6 seconds
answers.distractor_3: 8 seconds

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Space Margins
question.source: Increase your following distance to three seconds on high-speed roads and to four seconds in bad weather conditions or on uneven or slippery roads.

question.text: Pedestrians and cyclists are most at risk from vehicles because

answers.answer: they are more likely to be severely injured in a crash than car drivers and passengers
answers.distractor_1: they are not required to follow the rules of the road
answers.distractor_2: they are more often at fault when crashes occur
answers.distractor_3: they are slower

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road
question.source: Of all road users, pedestrians are among the most vulnerable. You always need to watch out for them. Pedestrians, like all road users, can be unpredictable.

question.text: What is the most immediate danger to Cyclist A?

answers.answer: The driver of Car B may not see Cyclist A and turn into its path.
answers.distractor_1: The pedestrian may move into Cyclist A's path.
answers.distractor_2: The driver of Car C may drive into the back of Cyclist A.
answers.distractor_3: The driver of Car D will turn left.

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road; Cyclists
question.source: Be aware that cyclists don't always stay on the right. To make a left turn, for instance, they need to move over to the left lane.

question.text: You MUST stop for a school bus

answers.answer: when its red lights are flashing
answers.distractor_1: at all times
answers.distractor_2: when it is carrying children
answers.distractor_3: when it is waiting by a school

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road; School buses
question.source: Stop whenever you see flashing lights on a school bus.

question.text: If you see pedestrians at the side of the road and wanting to jaywalk you should

answers.answer: slow down and be ready to stop
answers.distractor_1: maintain your speed as you have the right of way
answers.distractor_2: always stop and yield the right of way
answers.distractor_3: slow down and wave them across

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road; Pedestrians
question.source: You must always be prepared to stop if you see a pedestrian who is about to step out in front of you. However, don't encourage jaywalking.

question.text: Pedestrians with a white cane should be treated with extra care because

answers.answer: they might be uncertain when crossing a street
answers.distractor_1: they will walk across a street at any point
answers.distractor_2: they do not have to follow the rules of the road
answers.distractor_3: they will not hear your vehicle

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road; Pedestrians
question.source: Often, a blind or partially blind person will raise their cane when uncertain of crossing the street safely. That is your signal to stop.

question.text: Which car does NOT have an escape route if a problem occurs ahead?

answers.answer: Car A
answers.distractor_1: Car B
answers.distractor_2: Car C
answers.distractor_3: Car D

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Space Margins
question.source: Try to leave yourself an escape route when you are driving on a multi-lane highway. Then, if something happens in front, you can pull into another lane.

question.text: Car A

answers.answer: may not pass
answers.distractor_1: may pass with caution
answers.distractor_2: may pass on the right
answers.distractor_3: may not turn left over the line

question.chapter: Chapter 3: Signs, Signals and Road Markings
question.source: Yellow lines divide traffic moving in opposite directions. A broken line and a solid line mean you may pass only when it is safe and the broken line is on your side.

question.text: This sign means

answers.answer: road narrows ahead
answers.distractor_1: divided highway ends ahead
answers.distractor_2: lane ends ahead
answers.distractor_3: narrow structure ahead

question.chapter: Chapter 3: Signs, Signals and Road Markings
question.source: Most warning signs are yellow and diamond-shaped. They warn of possible hazards ahead.

question.text: Making eye contact with cyclists around your vehicle

answers.answer: is a good means of communication
answers.distractor_1: may cause them to lose balance
answers.distractor_2: may distract you
answers.distractor_3: is not useful

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road; Cyclists
question.source: A cyclist often relies on eye contact as a means of communication. Make eye contact if you can. She or he is probably trying to anticipate your next move.

question.text: If you notice a driver who is steering side to side or stopping without reason, you should

answers.answer: give yourself extra space
answers.distractor_1: follow them to their destination
answers.distractor_2: honk at them
answers.distractor_3: flash your lights and pass them

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Hazard Perception
question.source: To avoid surprises, think well ahead and ask yourself what could possibly happen in the driving environment.

question.text: Stopped public transit buses

answers.answer: may hide pedestrians who are preparing to cross
answers.distractor_1: require you to stop behind them
answers.distractor_2: can't see vehicles that will pass them
answers.distractor_3: have to honk before pulling into traffic

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road; Public Transit Buses
question.source: Watch for buses that have stopped -- they may block your view of pedestrians about to cross the street, or they may be about to pull into traffic.

question.text: When pulling out of a driveway on to a street with a sidewalk, what must the driver of Car A do before entering the street?

answers.answer: stop before the sidewalk
answers.distractor_1: be prepared to stop, but continue into the street if no hazard is identified.
answers.distractor_2: slow down and proceed with caution
answers.distractor_3: stop just past the sidewalk before entering the street

question.chapter: Chapter 4: Rules of the Road; Right-of-Way at Intersections
question.source: When you are pulling out of a driveway, alley or parking lot onto a road, stop before the sidewalk or area where pedestrians may be walking.

question.text: Your space margins are the distance between

answers.answer: your vehicle and other road users
answers.distractor_1: your vehicle and the vehicle ahead of you
answers.distractor_2: your vehicle and the vehicle behind you
answers.distractor_3: your vehicle and the curb

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Space Margins
question.source: You must have room to move if you need it. Space margins include your space in front, behind, beside and your lane position.

question.text: One danger of driving too close to the car in front of you is

answers.answer: you may not be able to see what is up ahead
answers.distractor_1: you will block the rear view mirror of the car in front
answers.distractor_2: you will force the car in front to speed up
answers.distractor_3: you will be in the blind spot of the car in front

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Space Margins
question.source: Tailgating (following too closely behind the vehicle in front) is a major cause of crashes. If you tailgate, the vehicle in front can block your view of hazards ahead.

question.text: Drivers should give cyclists extra room because they

answers.answer: might swerve or change lanes
answers.distractor_1: often stop suddenly
answers.distractor_2: often ride two abreast
answers.distractor_3: do not have to follow the same rules of the road

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road; Cyclists
question.source: Allow side margins - a significant number of crashes involving cyclists result from side-swiping. Make sure there is enough space if you want to pass a cyclist.

question.text: This car may

answers.answer: not pass but can turn left over the line
answers.distractor_1: pass but can't turn left over the line
answers.distractor_2: not pass or turn left over the line
answers.distractor_3: pass and turn left over the line

question.chapter: Chapter 3: Signs, Signals and Road Markings
question.source: Yellow lines divide traffic moving in opposite directions. A broken line and a solid line mean you may pass only when it is safe and the broken line is on your side.

question.text: You should never sneak behind a truck when it is backing up because

answers.answer: it is dangerous if you enter one of its blind spots
answers.distractor_1: they have a less effective braking system than cars
answers.distractor_2: they carry more weight than your vehicle
answers.distractor_3: the truck may create too much turbulence

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road; Large Vehicles
question.source: Never try to sneak behind a truck if it is backing into a loading bay or out of a driveway because you will enter one of the truck driver's blind spots and risk being hit.

question.text: You are driving along a multi-lane one way street. You see an emergency vehicle with lights flashing in your rear view mirror. You should

answers.answer: move safely to either side of the road and stop
answers.distractor_1: be ready to get out of the way
answers.distractor_2: slow down and move to either side of the road
answers.distractor_3: stop immediately

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road; Emergency Vehicles
question.source: Usually the best thing to do is pull over to the right and stop (or to the left if you're driving in the left lane of a divided highway or on a one-way street).

question.text: The traffic light for Car A has just turned green. An ambulance with flashing lights is coming up from behind. What should Car A do?

answers.answer: Turn right to clear a path for the ambulance.
answers.distractor_1: Back up and pull over to the curb.
answers.distractor_2: Honk at Car C to pull over to the curb.
answers.distractor_3: Speed up through the intersection

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road; Emergency Vehicles
question.source: If you are stopped at an intersection and you are blocking the path of the emergency vehicle, you may have to turn the corner to get out of the way.

question.text: You are driving in the LEFT lane of a DIVIDED highway. You see an emergency vehicle with lights flashing in your rear view mirror. You should

answers.answer: move safely to the nearest edge of the road and stop
answers.distractor_1: slow down and move to either side of the road
answers.distractor_2: stop immediately
answers.distractor_3: be ready to get out of the way

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road; Emergency Vehicles
question.source: Usually the best thing to do is pull over to the right and stop (or to the left if you are driving in the left lane of a divided highway or on a one-way street).

question.text: To make a left turn at this intersection, Vehicle A should

answers.answer: move to the left lane before turning
answers.distractor_1: turn from the centre lane
answers.distractor_2: turn from any lane
answers.distractor_3: move to the right lane before turning

question.chapter: Chapter 4: Rules of the Road; Using Lanes Correctly
question.source: Before you make a turn, you need to get your vehicle into the correct lane. Then you need to end up in the correct lane when you complete your turn.

question.text: After you have stopped at a steady red light, you may

answers.answer: turn right or turn left into a one-way street if it is safe and no signs prohibit it
answers.distractor_1: drive straight through
answers.distractor_2: turn left or right
answers.distractor_3: turn right only

question.chapter: Chapter 3: Signs, Signals and Road Markings
question.source: Watch for signs prohibiting you from making these turns on a red light.

question.text: What should you be prepared to do when being passed on a two lane road?

answers.answer: slow down and make room so that they may safely pass
answers.distractor_1: speed up to prevent them passing
answers.distractor_2: maintain your speed at all times
answers.distractor_3: maintain your speed while driving on the shoulder of the road

question.chapter: Chapter 4: Rules of the Road; Passing

question.text: What should the driver of Car A do?

answers.answer: Slow down and stop.
answers.distractor_1: Speed up to get through the crosswalk before the pedestrians step off the curb.
answers.distractor_2: Honk to warn the pedestrian.
answers.distractor_3: Slow down in case the pedestrians step into the crosswalk.

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road; Pedestrians
question.source: You must yield to pedestrians in marked crosswalks, if the pedestrian is close to your half of the road.

question.text: In this traffic circle, the driver of Vehicle A wants to head down Street B. The correct path is

answers.answer: to yield to traffic in the circle, turn right when safe, and exit right down Path B
answers.distractor_1: to turn left as soon as Motorcycle C passes by
answers.distractor_2: complete one full revolution of the traffic circle before exiting
answers.distractor_3: to wait until the traffic circle is empty, then turn left

question.chapter: Chapter 4: Rules of the Road; Right-of-Way at Intersections
question.source: All vehicles must turn right to enter a traffic circle and right again to leave it.

question.text: Car A and Car B arrived at the stop sign at the same time. Who should go first?

answers.answer: Car B.
answers.distractor_1: Car A.
answers.distractor_2: Both may move at the same time.
answers.distractor_3: Both should wait for Car C to reach the intersection.

question.chapter: Chapter 4: Rules of the Road; Right-of-Way at Intersections
question.source: If two vehicles arrive at a four-way stop at the same time, the one on the right should go first.

question.text: Car B arrived at the stop sign first. Who should go first?

answers.answer: Car B.
answers.distractor_1: Car A.
answers.distractor_2: Car B should wave Car A through.
answers.distractor_3: Both may go at the same time

question.chapter: Chapter 4: Rules of the Road; Right-of-Way at Intersections
question.source: The first vehicle to arrive at the intersection of a four-way stop and come to a complete stop should go first.

question.text: You are the driver of Car A and want to make a right turn. Which is the best See-Think-Do manoeuvre?

answers.answer: I see cyclist B approaching; I think, "The cyclist may be at the corner when I want to turn."; I slow down.
answers.distractor_1: I see the corner ahead; I think "I'm going to be late for a meeting."; I accelerate and turn.
answers.distractor_2: I see cyclist B; I think, "I can get to the corner first."; accelerate and turn.
answers.distractor_3: I see cyclist B; I think, "I have the right of way."; I honk, and make the turn.

question.chapter: Chapter 6: Sharing the Road; Cyclists
question.source: Yield to cyclists as you would to any other vehicle. If you have the right-of-way at an intersection, proceed if it is safe.

question.text: The traffic signal has just turned yellow. There are no other vehicles around. Vehicle A should

answers.answer: slow down and stop since it is safe to do so
answers.distractor_1: speed up and make it through before it turns red
answers.distractor_2: scan the intersection, maintain speed, and go straight through
answers.distractor_3: stop, and then proceed through the red light since there is no other traffic

question.chapter: Chapter 3: Signs, Signals and Road Markings
question.source: Yellow means that the signal is about the turn red. You must stop before entering the intersection unless you cannot safely stop in time.

question.text: Hand signals

answers.answer: should be used if turn signals are hard to see
answers.distractor_1: should always be used in good weather
answers.distractor_2: are only used by cyclists and motorcycle riders
answers.distractor_3: will only confuse others and should not be used

question.chapter: Chapter 5: See - Think - Do; Communication
question.source: There are times when an automatic turn signal is hard to see in these situations, use a hand signal in addition to the turn signal.

question.text: Before making a left turn, a driver should

answers.answer: yield to oncoming traffic and wait for a safe gap
answers.distractor_1: signal any drivers behind to pass
answers.distractor_2: make sure there are no cars behind
answers.distractor_3: wait for oncoming drivers to wave you through

question.chapter: Chapter 4: Rules of the Road; Right-of-Way at Intersections
question.source: When making a left turn on a green light, you must yield to oncoming traffic and wait for a safe gap before you turn.

question.text: When you see a solid white line on your left it means

answers.answer: you may not changes lanes
answers.distractor_1: it is separating traffic going in different directions.
answers.distractor_2: you may pass with caution.
answers.distractor_3: only public transit vehicles may pass.

question.chapter: Chapter 3: Signs, Signals and Road Markings
question.source: White lines are used to separate lanes of traffic moving in the same direction. A solid line means do not change lanes.

question.text: The driver of Car A should

answers.answer: enter freeway at the speed of traffic flow
answers.distractor_1: move into the far left lane as soon as possible
answers.distractor_2: drive faster than traffic flow to better maneuver
answers.distractor_3: slow down before entering the freeway

question.chapter: Chapter 4: Rules of the Road; Highway or Freeway Entrances and Exits
question.source: A highway entrance gives you a short distance to match your speed to the vehicles already on the highway.

question.text: In the ACCELERATION lane before merging on to a highway, a driver should

answers.answer: speed up to match the speed of traffic.
answers.distractor_1: signal and pull into the flow of traffic.
answers.distractor_2: only be looking straight ahead.
answers.distractor_3: be looking in the rear view mirror.

question.chapter: Chapter 4: Rules of the Road; Highway or Freeway Entrances and Exits
question.source: The acceleration lane is divided from the rest of the roadway by a solid white line. Use this lane to match your speed to the speed of the traffic on the freeway.

question.text: When exiting a highway you should slow down

answers.answer: after you are in the exit lane.
answers.distractor_1: before you are in the exit lane.
answers.distractor_2: before you signal your intention to turn off the highway.
answers.distractor_3: only if there are vehicles behind you.

question.chapter: Chapter 4: Rules of the Road
question.source: Signal your intention to turn off the highway, maintaining your speed until you enter the exit lane. Then slow down gradually as you prepare to enter roads with lower speed limits.

question.text: This sign tells you

answers.answer: the fastest you may drive under ideal conditions
answers.distractor_1: that there is a faster speed limit ahead
answers.distractor_2: the ideal speed for this road in any conditions
answers.distractor_3: the maximum speed unless you are passing

question.chapter: Chapter 3: Signs, Signals and Road Markings
question.source: Regulatory signs tell you about driving laws and regulations. It is an offence under the B.C. Motor Vehicle Act to disregard them.

question.text: This sign means:

answers.answer: do not pass
answers.distractor_1: there is only single lane traffic ahead
answers.distractor_2: the road is for one way traffic only
answers.distractor_3: there is a divided road ahead

question.chapter: Chapter 3: Signs, Signals and Road Markings
question.source: Regulatory signs tell you about driving laws and regulations. It is an offence under the B.C. Motor Vehicle Act to disregard them.

question.text: This sign warns,

answers.answer: a school bus stop is ahead
answers.distractor_1: an oncoming vehicle's lights will be flashing
answers.distractor_2: a vehicle with its hazard lights flashing is ahead
answers.distractor_3: a fire truck zone is ahead

question.chapter: Chapter 3: Signs, Signals and Road Markings
question.source: Most warning signs are yellow and diamond-shaped. They warn of possible hazards ahead.

question.text: This sign means that in this lane, you must

answers.answer: turn left only
answers.distractor_1: turn left or go straight ahead
answers.distractor_2: turn right only
answers.distractor_3: not turn left

question.chapter: Chapter 3: Signs, Signals and Road Markings
question.source: Lane use signs are signs showing which lanes may be used to turn or go straight and are mounted above the lane or at the side of the lane before the intersection.

question.text: This sign, without a speed tab below, means

answers.answer: school zone - reduce speed when children are present
